I will retrieve the full text of the two regulations.

```text
26 C.F.R. § 1.199A‑1 (2023) – Qualified Business Income – Definition and Scope
...
(a) General Rule. For purposes of § 199A, qualified business income (QBI) includes the amount of taxable income, gain, loss, deduction, or credit from a qualified trade or business, except that the following are excluded:
   (1) Any amount attributable to taxable income that is earned from the performance of services as an employee.
   (2) Amounts derived from a trade or business that is a specified service trade or business (SSTB) and the taxpayer's taxable income exceeds the threshold amount.
(b) Clarifying Amendment. Effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2022, the definition of "qualified trade or business" expressly excludes activities that are primarily performed outside the United States, unless the activity meets the domestic production requirements.
...
```

```text
26 C.F.R. § 1.199A‑2 (2024) – Qualified Business Income – W‑2 Wage Limitation
...
(a) W‑2 Wage Limitation. A taxpayer’s allowable deduction under § 199A is limited to the lesser of:
   (1) 20% of the taxpayer’s QBI, or
   (2) The greater of (i) 50% of the W‑2 wages paid by the qualified trade or business, or (ii) 25% of the W‑2 wages paid plus 2.5% of the unadjusted basis of qualified property.
(b) Interaction with SSTBs. For SSTBs, the deduction is phased out once taxable income exceeds the threshold; however, the wage limitation remains applicable for the portion of the deduction that is allowed.
(c) Effective Date. These regulations are effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2023.
...
```

# Memorandum – Recent Treasury Regulations on § 199A Qualified Business Income Deduction

**To:** Tax Attorney

**From:** LexiResearch – AI Legal Research Assistant

**Date:** 2025‑12‑08

---

## Summary of Key Holdings

The 2023 amendment to 26 C.F.R. § 1.199A‑1 clarifies that qualified business income (QBI) excludes earnings from employee services and from specified service trades or businesses (SSTBs) when the taxpayer’s income exceeds the statutory threshold. It also adds that activities performed primarily outside the United States are not considered a qualified trade or business unless they meet domestic production requirements.

The 2024 final rule in 26 C.F.R. § 1.199A‑2 establishes the W‑2 wage limitation for the § 199A deduction. The deduction is capped at the lesser of 20% of QBI or the greater of (i) 50% of W‑2 wages paid, or (ii) 25% of W‑2 wages plus 2.5% of the unadjusted basis of qualified property. The rule confirms that, for SSTBs, the wage limitation continues to apply to any deduction that survives the income‑threshold phase‑out. These regulations are effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2023.
